captions.text:
I never played soccer
during recess in school;
but I didn't stay seated either

and I did what the rest
of my friends did.

Some of my best friends
didn't like sports,

but for fear of being different,
of the unknown,

they continued, literally
"stuck to the ball"
during the breaks between classes.
It was really clear to me;
that I wanted to pursue my passions.

For most of my life, I wanted 
to dedicate time to what I liked.

Since childhood, not caring 
about what people said,

I wouldn't stop drawing,
acting or painting.
Today, having recently turned nineteen,

it's very simple for me
to make this kind of assertions.

However, in society there's 
a great fear of what is different

and, above all, a rejection
of what is not identifiable.

As a result, unfortunately
for many years
I was the target fo harsh criticisms.

I remember, when I was 4 or 5,
I was always drawing figures
of slender and graceful women.

Figures full of color 
and imagination.
I fondly recall that time
when, to paint the heads,
I had to use the top of the glue stick;

or when my little sister
asked me, or not,

I would draw the coats and dresses
for some of her dolls.

So in high school,
I spontaneously decided,
to lead various creative activities.

I founded a magazine together
with my best friends,

I was a choir soloist
for 5 years,
and I led a debate team.
Fashion was already a part of me,

but I didn't have 
any public exposure for it,

rather it stayed with me 
as you all see, in a more personal way.
At 14, I began to almost fight myself,

going by the most important 
catwalks in the country
and also throughout Europe.

I have to say, my first
contact with real fashion
didn't convince me

and many things still
don't convince me today.

A year later, I began 
to use my vacation time

to study art and fashion
in capital cities
like Paris, Florence and London.

>From those studies
I was lucky to make
as I'm always one of the smallest,

and honestly those experiences
allowed me to know

and come into contact
with other cultures, and to understand
other points of view.

They eventually helped me
consolidate my love for this art.
Now I'm in undergrad, I decided...

well, I wanted to choose
that class option

that I was thinking about 
many years before signing up right?
The humanities, the branch of humanities.
Not everybody is an engineer!

But certainly it is because of 
the study of subjects like

art history, classic Greek or Latin,
that one can understand

or know these bases
and how they support

Western culture
in all of its aspects.
This same year, these two years,

I could combine
my studies and fashion

and with a good friend,
who's in the audience,

we created a small workshop where
we developed a beneficial outlet.

With this project we continued 
to be united through our passion,

because all of the benefits were going
towards the fight against poverty,

through various NGOs 
we collaborated with

and continue collaborating with
at university.

I finalized high school,
and the time came
for me to choose a major for college.

Finally, I'd be able to use all of
my time for creativity.

At home, nobody was surprised 
by my decision,

they know me better than 
anybody
and firmly supported my decision.

On the other hand, my best friends
celebrated my decision with me.

I see fashion as an expression
of art and communication.

What makes me passionate
about it can be summed up

in a sentence by the Spanish designer
Cristobal Balenciaga:

"A good designer should be:
an architect for patterns,

a sculptor for form,
a painter for drawing,

music for harmony and
philosopher for measure".

I would add: "and communicator so
that message can reach everybody".

I also want to share with you all
today some of my projects.

Already, I have discovered that
I cannot stop loving what is different;

this idea seems to stay with me, 
but I certainly run away

from the "mainstream" fashion,
therefore what is fashionable.

And I've discovered that
there's a lot to do,

a lot to work on
and above all a lot to learn.

Fashion isn't just one of 
the main economic drives of the world,

is one of the areas where
the human factor and the environment

in the processes of production.
are less taken into account.
I imagine that everybody remembers

that scandal about the factories
in Bangladesh, for example.

That's certainly made me think
these past years,
and with another friend,
I started to create a new project.

Within reason, I looked for 
better care in the production,

manufacturing, and traceability
of the product.

I bet on Spain,
a rich and different country,

a meeting point of different 
cultures throughout history,

and a nation with a 
notable textile tradition.
That is my new dream,

a fashion project for men,
fresh and natural,

that supports quality
and is ethical,
and that for now is in its beginning.

Before I finish, I would like
to take this opportunity

to send a message to all of
those in charge of education:

ask yourself if such a categorized
educative system is worth it,

when it doesn't encourage the abilities
and qualities of each person.

I also have a message for all the children
and young people around the world:
I invite you to be different

and to fight for what
really makes you passionate.

Remember that Nelson Mandela
was "the different one" in his community

and he succeeded in putting 
an end to apartheid.

Mother Teresa loved differently,
kissing the poorest,

and she has become
a model of dedication for society.

And in terms of design,
Yves Saint Laurent,

couldn't survive in the army
during the war of Argelia,

he took the alternative: fashion
and its legacy survives to this day.
I don't know my future,

but I often think about something
that Coco Chanel said on occasion:

"To be irreplaceable, one should 
always seek to be different".
Thanks a lot!
(Applause)

title: La pasion de ser diferente | Bosco Tamames | TEDxYouth@Madrid
